awd_titl_txt: Evaluating competing models of human technological adaptation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Brian Wood at the University of California, Los Angeles, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist investigating the relative roles of culture and cause-and-effect cognition in the formation and maintenance of technological traditions. This project seeks to (1) build upon theoretical and experimental research as to the importance of causal knowledge and culture in the evolution of technology using empirical data; (2) produce a comprehensive theoretical model of technological evolution; and (3) assemble a detailed archive of the current projectile technological stylistic and mechanistic variation.

Competing models of human evolution differentially emphasize the roles of cumulative culture and individual cause-and-effect knowledge in the evolution of complex technology. This project will examine the capacities that underlie our ability to manufacture complex technologies, an ability that has underwritten our evolutionary success and subsequent expansion across the world’s habitats. Previous studies examining the relative roles of causal understanding and culture in the development of complex technologies are largely theoretical and limited by the uncertainty of their external validity. The goal of this project is to evaluate competing models of human technological adaptation using empirical data. The opportunity to examine these processes in a naturalistic setting, allows us to test the generality of prior research findings arising from experimental settings. To address the research objectives of this project, a combination of technology-focused interviews, structured behavioral observations, and guided focal-follows will be performed. The proposed project will contribute new knowledge about the relative importance of cultural, cognitive, and environmental covariates necessary in the manufacture, use, and evolution of complex technology by testing hypotheses about technological expertise and material culture variation within an ethnographic context. Finally, the proposed project will provide a detailed portrait of material cultural variation that can be compared to other cultural contexts and used to track the evolution of this technology over time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project outcomes of the award titled, “Evaluating competing models of human technological adaptation” include the completion of two field seasons, the collection of multifaceted ethnographic data, one peer-reviewed journal article currently in revisions for Human Nature, and journal articles currently in progress. The article in revision is titled “Hadza Landscape Burning”, and the authors include Jacob Harris, Mariamu Anyawire, Audax Mabulla, and Brian Wood. As I describe in greater detail below, the project outcomes directly address the specific intellectual merits and broader impacts described in the award proposal.

     Under the guidance of Mentor, Dr. Brian Wood, the National Science Foundation Fellow, Dr. Jacob Harris, complete two trips to Tanzania to work among and with Hadza hunter-gatherers. A primary intellectual merit of this project was a contribution to evolutionary studies of human cognition and cumulative cultural evolution by evaluating hypotheses about technological expertise and material culture variation within an ethnographic context. Dr. Harris has made significant progress toward this goal through the collection of detailed interviews exploring multiple aspects of traditional technologies utilized by Hadza hunter-gatherers with a focus on two key technologies: projectile technology and landscape burning.

     We interviewed members of the Hadza community, including both men and women, from six different camps regarding technological and behavioral adaptations crucial to the Hadza’s chosen way of life. We collected high-resolution photographic, video, and GPS data associated with landscape burning. We also collected interview, photographic, video, and GPS data surveying the collection of raw materials used in the manufacture of projectile technology and the transmission of technological knowledge. Our detailed record of Hadza projectile technology will allow us to accomplish a key intellectual merit outlined in the study proposal – a longitudinal and cross-cultural examination of the evolution of traditional technology. The multifaceted data collected in this study will allow us to observe and track how Hadza projectile technology responds to short and long-term environmental fluctuation as well as inter-group cultural interactions over a several years, providing valuable insights into the logic and culturally embedded design processes governing material cultural variation. The video, photograph, GPS, and interview data we collected are complex and rich in the information they possess. This project has also produced numerous opportunities for student involvement in the coding, processing, and preliminary analysis of data. Six undergraduate research assistants are currently engaged in the coding and preliminary analyses of data.

     We have achieved this study's broader impacts by successfully documenting, archiving, and preparing for analysis, key aspects of Hadza material culture and traditional landscape management practices. The extensive photographic record of projectile technology includes high-resolution photography, photogrammetry, and a database of metrics associated with both bow and arrow mechanics and stylistic variation. Photographic data are being processed to produce a database of the Hadza projectile technology used by the study participants. A video record, documenting the manufacture of projectile technology and the social learning of projectile designs was also collected and archived. The video record includes many hours of bow and arrow making by Hadza men and boys and includes numerous instances of both active and passive teaching. The video record represents an invaluable documentary into how Hadza men manufacture projectile technology and how the skills are transmitted and learned by other members of the community.

     PI, Jacob Harris has also been involved in community outreach and education in the context of this project. Owing in part to his NSF-supported research, Dr. Harris was recently hired as a tenure-track faculty member at Arizona State University (ASU), and in this role continues to engage with groups of undergraduate and graduate students about this research. This includes advising students, formal instruction, and numerous instances of public engagement including the public event “Night of the Open Door” at ASU where the local community is invited to explore laboratories, collections, and facilities usually closed off to the public. In his current faculty position at ASU, Dr. Harris will continue to analyze and publish the data collected during his postdoctoral fellowship, addressing his overarching research questions concerning human technological evolution.
